revision.comment: new key for [[Category:Lists of dynasties]]: "Roman" using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
This is a list of the [[Dynasty|dynasties]] that ruled the [[Roman Empire]] and its two succeeding counterparts, the [[Western Roman Empire]] and the [[Byzantine Empire]] (Eastern Roman Empire). Dynasties of states that had [[Third Rome|claimed legal succession]] from the Roman Empire are not included in this list. ==List of Roman dynasties== {| class="wikitable" style="width:1100" |- !rowspan="2"|Dynasty !colspan="3"|Period of rule !colspan="3"|Rulers |- !Start !End !Term !First to rule !Last to rule !List |- !colspan="7"|Dynasties of the [[Principate]] |- |[[Julio-Claudian dynasty|Julio–Claudian dynasty]] |27 BCE{{cite book|last1=Kidner|first1=Frank|last2=Bucur|first2=Maria|last3=Mathisen|first3=Ralph|last4=McKee|first4=Sally|last5=Weeks|first5=Theodore|title=Making Europe: The Story of the West|year=2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1_E_CQAAQBAJ&pg=PA161&dq=julio+claudian+dynasty+27+bc-68+ad&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjQvsmQrZnnAhVTU30KHY2gB1sQ6AEIVDAF#v=onepage&q=julio%20claudian%20dynasty%2027%20bc-68%20ad&f=false|page=161}} |68 CE |95 years |[[Augustus]] |[[Nero]] |([[List of Roman emperors#27 BC–68 AD: Julio-Claudian dynasty|list]]) |- |[[Flavian dynasty]] |69 CE |96 CE |27 years |[[Vespasian]] |[[Domitian]] |([[List of Roman emperors#68–96: Year of the Four Emperors and Flavian dynasty|list]]) |- |[[Nerva–Antonine dynasty]]{{efn|name="Nerva–Antonine"|The [[Nerva–Antonine dynasty]] is sometimes subdivided into the [[Nerva–Antonine dynasty#Nerva–Trajan dynasty|Nerva–Trajan dynasty]] and the [[Nerva–Antonine dynasty#Antonine dynasty|Antonine dynasty]].}} |96 CE{{cite book|last1=D'Amato|first1=Raffaele|last2=Frediani|first2=Andrea|title=Strasbourg AD 357: The victory that saved Gaul|year=2019|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6mObDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA8&dq=Nerva–Antonine+dynasty+96-192&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi8lvner5nnAhVRcCsKHbEpDWAQ6AEIODAC#v=onepage&q=Nerva–Antonine%20dynasty%2096-192&f=false|page=8}} |192 CE |96 years |[[Nerva]] |[[Commodus]] |([[List of Roman emperors#96–192: Nerva–Antonine dynasty|list]]) |- |[[Severan dynasty]] |193 CE{{cite book|last1=Ermatinger|first1=James|title=The Roman Empire: A Historical Encyclopedia|year=2018|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=onlUDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA233&dq=Severan+dynasty+193-235&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiDoPqhsJnnAhUIbisKHT44D84Q6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=Severan%20dynasty%20193-235&f=false|page=233}} |235 CE |42 years |[[Septimius Severus]] |[[Severus Alexander]] |([[List of Roman emperors#193–235: Year of the Five Emperors and Severan dynasty|list]]) |- |[[Gordian dynasty]] |238 CE{{cite book|last1=Fomenko|first1=Anatoly|title=History: Fiction Or Science?|year=2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fSvlaZYbcwUC&pg=PA171&dq=Gordian+dynasty+238-244&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj88rUsZnnAhVNeH0KHZI4A7EQ6AEIMTAB#v=onepage&q=Gordian%20dynasty%20238-244&f=false|page=171}} |244 CE |6 years |[[Gordian I]] |[[Gordian III]] |([[List of Roman emperors#235–285: Gordian dynasty and Crisis of the Third Century|list]]) |- |Decian dynasty |249 CE |251 CE |2 years |[[Decius]] |[[Hostilian]] |([[Crisis of the Third Century#Decian dynasty|list]]) |- |Valerian dynasty |253 CE |268 CE |15 years |[[Valerian (emperor)|Valerian]] |[[Gallienus]] |([[Crisis of the Third Century#Valerian dynasty|list]]) |- |Caran dynasty |282 CE |285 CE |3 years |[[Carus]] |[[Carinus]] |([[Crisis of the Third Century#Caran dynasty|list]]) |- !colspan="7"|Dynasties of the [[Dominate]] |- |[[Constantinian dynasty]]{{efn|name="Constantinian"|The [[Constantinian dynasty]] is also known as the "Neo-Flavian dynasty".}} |305 CE{{cite book|last1=Cowell|first1=Frank|title=Everyday Life in Ancient Rome|year=1961|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MEdoAAAAMAAJ&q=Constantinian+dynasty+305-363&dq=Constantinian+dynasty+305-363&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj318_espnnAhVZcCsKHTdGAF4Q6AEIODAC|page=199}} |363 CE |58 years |[[Constantius Chlorus]]
{{small|(Western)}}
[[Constantine the Great|Constantine I]]
{{small|(Eastern)}} |[[Julian (emperor)|Julian]]
{{small|(Western & Eastern)}} |([[List of Roman emperors#284–364: Tetrarchy and Constantinian dynasty|list]]) |- |[[Valentinian dynasty]] |364 CE{{cite book|last1=Christ|first1=Karl|title=The Romans: An Introduction to Their History and Civilisation|year=1984|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YHXveBhJhlsC&pg=PA184&dq=Valentinian+dynasty+364-392&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjuoI7Vs5nnAhUQb30KHcGKCp4Q6AEIRjAE#v=onepage&q=Valentinian%20dynasty%20364-392&f=false|page=184}} |392 CE |28 years |[[Valentinian I]]
{{small|(Western & Eastern)}} |[[Valens]]
{{small|(Eastern)}}
[[Valentinian II]]
{{small|(Western)}} |([[List of Roman emperors#364–392: Valentinian dynasty|list]]) |- |[[Theodosian dynasty]] |379 CE{{cite book|last1=Grig|first1=Lucy|last2=Kelly|first2=Gavin|title=Two Romes: Rome and Constantinople in Late Antiquity|year=2015|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sGNnDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA186&dq=Theodosian+dynasty+379-457&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjW5YOltJnnAhVPXn0KHeo_DdQQ6AEIOjAC#v=onepage&q=Theodosian%20dynasty%20379-457&f=false|page=186}} |457 CE |78 years |[[Theodosius I]]
{{small|(Western & Eastern)}} |[[Valentinian III]]
{{small|(Western)}}
[[Marcian]]
{{small|(Eastern)}} |([[List of Roman emperors#392–455: Theodosian dynasty|list W]])
([[List of Byzantine emperors#Theodosian dynasty (379–457)|list E]]) |- !colspan="7"|Eastern (Byzantine) dynasties |- |[[House of Leo|Leonid dynasty]] |457 CE{{cite book|last1=Maas|first1=Michael|title=The Cambridge Companion to the Age of Attila|year=2015|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=67dUBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA106&dq=house+of+Leo+457-518&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjyu4z8tJnnAhUSWX0KHVCcAr4Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=house%20of%20Leo%20457-518&f=false|page=106}} |518 CE |61 years |[[Leo I the Thracian|Leo I]] |[[Anastasius I Dicorus|Anastasius I]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Leonid dynasty (457–518)|list]]) |- |[[Byzantine Empire under the Justinian dynasty|Justinian dynasty]] |518 CE{{cite book|last1=Konstam|first1=Angus|title=Byzantine Warship vs Arab Warship: 7th–11th centuries|year=2015|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tj-VCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA18&dq=Justinian+dynasty+518-602&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwigk92vtZnnAhXIR30KHapPDF8Q6AEIMTAB#v=onepage&q=Justinian%20dynasty%20518-602&f=false|page=18}} |602 CE |84 years |[[Justin I]] |[[Maurice (emperor)|Maurice]]
''and''
[[Theodosius (son of Maurice)|Theodosius]]{{efn|name="Justinian"|[[Maurice (emperor)|Maurice]] and [[Theodosius (son of Maurice)|Theodosius]] reigned as co-rulers.}} |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Justinian dynasty (518–602)|list]]) |- |[[Byzantine Empire under the Heraclian dynasty|Heraclian dynasty]] |610 CE{{cite book|last1=Flichy|first1=Thomas|title=Financial Crises and Renewal of Empires|year=2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eZDxAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=Heraclian+dynasty+610-711&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3gODrtZnnAhUNYysKHcIoDf0Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Heraclian%20dynasty%20610-711&f=false|page=30}} |711 CE |91 years{{efn|name="Heraclian1"|The rule of the [[Byzantine Empire under the Heraclian dynasty|Heraclian dynasty]] was interrupted between 695 CE and 705 CE. [[Justinian II]] was both the last ruler before the interregnum and the first ruler after the interregnum.}} |[[Heraclius]] |[[Justinian II]]
''and''
[[Tiberius (son of Justinian II)|Tiberius]]{{efn|name="Heraclian2"|[[Justinian II]] and [[Tiberius (son of Justinian II)|Tiberius]] reigned as co-rulers.}} |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Heraclian dynasty (610–695)|list]]) |- |[[Byzantine Empire under the Isaurian dynasty|Isaurian dynasty]]{{efn|name="Isaurian"|The [[Byzantine Empire under the Isaurian dynasty|Isaurian dynasty]] is also known as the "Syrian dynasty".}} |717 CE{{cite book|last1=LePree|first1=James|last2=Djukic|first2=Ljudmila|title=The Byzantine Empire: A Historical Encyclopedia|year=2019|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q6KsDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA209&dq=Isaurian+dynasty+717-802&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3to2Vt5nnAhUEVysKHTbDDMIQ6AEIODAC#v=onepage&q=Isaurian%20dynasty%20717-802&f=false|page=209}} |802 CE |85 years |[[Leo III the Isaurian|Leo III]] |[[Irene of Athens]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Isaurian dynasty (717–802)|list]]) |- |[[Byzantine Empire under the Nikephorian dynasty|Nikephorian dynasty]] |802 CE |813 CE |11 years |[[Nikephoros I]] |[[Michael I Rangabe]]
''and''
[[Theophylact (son of Michael I)|Theophylact]]{{efn|name="Nikephorian"|[[Michael I Rangabe]] and [[Theophylact (son of Michael I)|Theophylact]] reigned as co-rulers.}} |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Nikephorian dynasty (802–813)|list]]) |- |[[Byzantine Empire under the Amorian dynasty|Amorian dynasty]]{{efn|name="Amorian"|The [[Byzantine Empire under the Amorian dynasty|Amorian dynasty]] is also known as the "Phrygian dynasty".}} |820 CE{{cite book|last1=Tougher|first1=Shaun|title=The Eunuch in Byzantine History and Society|year=2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f7yNAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA55&dq=Amorian+dynasty+820-867&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwir7OmsuJnnAhWUfn0KHcrDCQgQ6AEIMTAB#v=onepage&q=Amorian%20dynasty%20820-867&f=false|page=55}} |867 CE |47 years |[[Michael II]] |[[Michael III]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Amorian dynasty (820–867)|list]]) |- |[[Macedonian dynasty]] |867 CE |1056 CE |189 years |[[Basil I]] |[[Theodora Porphyrogenita (11th century)|Theodora Porphyrogenita]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Macedonian dynasty (867–1056)|list]]) |- |[[Komnenos|Komnenid dynasty]]{{efn|name="Komnenid1"|The [[Komnenos|Komnenid dynasty]] ruled the [[Empire of Trebizond]] between 1204 CE and 1461 CE.}} |1057 CE{{cite book|last1=Walker|first1=Alicia|title=The Emperor and the World: Exotic Elements and the Imaging of Middle Byzantine Imperial Power, Ninth to Thirteenth Centuries C.E.|year=2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XrOGt6CpTgMC&pg=PA11&dq=Komnenos+dynasty+1057-1185&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwil_anruJnnAhUbT30KHZRZAs0Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Komnenos%20dynasty%201057-1185&f=false|page=11}} |1185 CE |106 years{{efn|name="Komnenid2"|The rule of the [[Komnenos|Komnenid dynasty]] was interrupted between 1059 CE and 1081 CE. [[Isaac I Komnenos]] was the last ruler before the interregnum. [[Alexios I Komnenos]] was the first ruler after the interregnum.}} |[[Isaac I Komnenos]] |[[Andronikos I Komnenos]]
''and''
[[John Komnenos (son of Andronikos I)|John Komnenos]]{{efn|name="Komnenid3"|[[Andronikos I Komnenos]] and [[John Komnenos (son of Andronikos I)|John Komnenos]] reigned as co-rulers.}} |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Komnenid dynasty (1081–1185)|list]]) |- |[[Doukas|Doukid dynasty]] |1059 CE{{cite book|last1=Stacton|first1=David|title=The World on the Last Day: The Sack of Constantinople by the Turks, May 29, 1453: Its Causes and Consequences|year=1965|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gvM-AQAAIAAJ&q=Doukas+1059-1078&dq=Doukas+1059-1078&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGlovFuZnnAhWQaCsKHSObA1wQ6AEIRjAE|page=276}} |1078 CE |19 years |[[Constantine X Doukas]] |[[Michael VII Doukas]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Doukid dynasty (1059–1081)|list]]) |- |[[Angelos|Angelid dynasty]] |1185 CELePree & Djukic (2019). p. 305. |1204 CE |19 years |[[Isaac II Angelos]] |[[Alexios V Doukas]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Angelid dynasty (1185–1204)|list]]) |- |[[Laskaris|Laskarid dynasty]]{{efn|name="Nicaea"|The [[Laskaris|Laskarid dynasty]] of the [[Empire of Nicaea]] during the [[Fourth Crusade]] is considered as the legitimate continuation of the Roman Empire.}} |1205 CE |1261 CE |56 years |[[Theodore I Laskaris]] |[[John IV Laskaris]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Laskarid dynasty (Empire of Nicaea, 1204–1261)|list]]) |- |[[Palaiologos|Palaiologan dynasty]] |1259 CE{{cite book|last1=Woodfin|first1=Warren|title=The Embodied Icon: Liturgical Vestments and Sacramental Power in Byzantium|year=2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cx3w6nqT17cC&pg=PR25&dq=Palaiologos+dynasty+1259-1453&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjTtfX-upnnAhWRbSsKHR4JBHEQ6AEIKzAA#v=onepage&q=Palaiologos%20dynasty%201259-1453&f=false|page=xxv}} |1453 CE |194 years |[[Michael VIII Palaiologos]] |[[Constantine XI Palaiologos]] |([[List of Byzantine emperors#Palaiologan dynasty (restored to Constantinople, 1261–1453)|list]]) |} ==Graphical
